title: EM waves - rank f for blue and IR in air and glass

content.description: Two electromagnetic waves, initially traveling in air, each reach a boundary with a piece of glass and are transmitted into the glass. One of the waves is blue visible light, the other wave is infrared, and the wavelengths in air of the two waves differ by a factor of two. If the glass has an index of refraction equal to <math alttext="1.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.5</mn></math>, how do the following four frequencies compare to one another?
content.question: <math alttext="f sub B comma air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>B,air</mtext></msub></math>, the frequency of the blue-light wave in vacuum<math alttext="f sub B comma glass" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>B,glass</mtext></msub></math>, the frequency of the blue-light wave in the glass<math alttext="f sub I R comma air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>IR,air</mtext></msub></math>, the frequency of the infrared wave in vacuum<math alttext="f sub I R comma glass" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>IR,glass</mtext></msub></math>, the frequency of the infrared wave in the glass

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
